Dean Doubts Vacation Cut
By NIELS SUNDERMEYER
The 19-inch snowfall which
paralyzed the city and closed
the Homewood Schools for two
days earlier this week is expected "not seriously to hamper
the University," according to
Homewood Dean Dr. G. Wilson
Shaffer.
"I think the University got
to work pretty fast, considering
conditions," Dr. Shaffer commented to the News - Letter
earlier this week. "The major
difficulty was the cold; the
workers couldn't make headway
because they had to keep stopping to get warm and the wind
caused drifts to cover their
work," Dr. Shaffer explained.
A grader and snowplow accomplished most of the work in
clearing campus roads Tuesday,
while maintenance men shovelled huge drifts frorn campus
pavements.

The blizzard, the worst such
in 16 years, paralyzed city
streets and transportation and
left the area in silent confusion
after a steady 18-hour deluge
last weekend. Twelve persons
were reported dead and thousands stranded on roadways and
parking areas. One Hopkins
student returning from Virginia
on Sunday reported a delay of
9 hours 5 miles outside the city
limits.

success achieved in attempts to
clear the Homewood campus
and parking areas. During the
2-day forced vacation a number
of students were hired by the
University to shovel the walks
near the dormitories. _Others

playing cards or studying.

parking were the biggest factors

in prompting Dr. Shaffer to
cancel classes in the Hopkins
and

Comedy of Errors
Although on the surface it appears that the IFB is
doing a good job this year, if one scratches the epidermis,
a series of mishaps and miscalculations are revealed which
more than suggest that Decker and Co. has been sloughing
off in monstrous proportions.
We shall commence at the genesis of this administration. The fall formal, originally scheduled, was rescheduled due to a conflict with a Barnstormer date. This
miscalculation cost the IFB the use of the Dixie Ballroom,
the band it had originally contracted, and $417.38 of extraneous gymnasium costs, such as tables, chairs, linen,
service charges, and damage done to three decorative pine
trees.
Then the Bowman Cup, which was not presented on
time to AD, is less than half the size of the original cup,
retired this year by Phi Ep. The Bowman Certificates
have not yet been printed, because they are locked in the
IFB filing cabinet, and the keys are lost. The keys were
also lost to the office of the Vigilance Committee, hence no
fraternity has sat vigilance duty for months. But it makes
little difference anyway, as the phone has been taken out
of the office because Decker neither handed over phone bills
nor money to secretary-treasurer Maseritz.
If one recalls the Phi Sig-Phi Ep "dirty" rushing incident of the past semester, he will also recall the $100
fine levied against each fraternity, and the threat that the
involved freshmen would be called before the Board for
a thorough castigation and indocrination into the ways of
gentlemanly rushing. The freshmen were never called;
Phi Ep is yet to pay up; no $100, hence no paid phone
bills, hence no vigilance duty.
The committee established before Christmas vacation
to report upon a new rush system has not only failed to
report, but has also failed to meet in full force. At IFB
meetings, the recorder, never mimeos the minutes; consequently Maseritz shoulders the responsibility. When
questions of constitutionality arise, a constitution is never
available.
These are just the highlights.. Let's all have a good
laugh at the IFB's incompetence, and trust that it better
damn sight get on the ball.

The Facts of Life
Reaction to the announcement that the entering
Freshmen of September, 1958, will not be allowed to park
cars on the campus if they reside more than three-quarters
of a mile from the University, has been mixed. We have
heard everything from indignant "I don't like it one damn
bit," to "I don't have any kick. At other schools I wouldn't
even be able to have a car until my senior year."
The facts of life in regard to the University parking
dilemma are quite simple: there are too many cars for
available parking spaces. The answer to the problem isn't
so simple. The parking commission took the action because it felt that there were no more parking spaces available. Others have disputed this.
Wyman Park has been suggested, but typographical
studies of the area indicate that development would be
very expensive. It takes a 65 foot strip for two rows of
cars. Parking garages are extremely expensive. Underground facilities cost well over $2000 per car: Above-theground structures are priced at a minimum of $1300 per
car. The garages have not been discarded but they would
be a last step, for operation would be both difficult and
costly.
A third possibility is the further development of the
existing lot near the faculty club. We have not been given
a satisfactory answer as to why this area can't be expanded.
Since there are many more registered cars than available spaces, the only way the maximum number of drivers
can be accommodated is to have turnover. This new rule
is aimed at achieving greater turnover, to eliminate the
cars that are parked for days at a time.
But the dormitory residents need help also. We have
petitioned the parking commission requesting that they try
to have the two hour parking limit recinded on Charles
Street. At the present time the University parking facilities, with the exception of the tiny dormitory, lot, are
third choice for dormitory residents. Charles St. and
University Parkway are first on the list. Thus if the
parking commission can persuade the City to allow unlimited parking on the adjacent streets, the on-campus
storage problem will be greatly reduced.

THE PLEDGE YOU SAVE
MAY BE YOUR OWN
Today's column is directed at those young female undergraduates who have recently pledged sororities and are worried, poor
lambs, that they won't make good. Following is a list of simple
instructions which,if faithfully observed, will positively guarantee that you will be a mad success LIS a sorority girl.
First, let us take up the matter of housemothers. The housemother is your friend, your guide, your mentor. You must treat
her with respect. When you wish to speak to her, address her as
"Mother Sigafoos" or "Ma'am." In no circumstances must you
say,"Hey, fat lady.",
Second, let us discuss laundry. Never hang your wash on the
front porch of the sorority house. This is unsightly and shows
a want of breeding. Use the Chapter Room.
Third, meals. Always remember that planning and preparing
meals for a houseful of healthy girls is no simple task. Your cook
goes to a great deal of trouble to make your menu varied and
nourishing. The least you can do is show your appreciation.
Don't just devour your food; praise it. Exclaim with delight,
!What delicious pork jowls!" or "What a yummy soupbone l'!
or "What scrumptious fish heads!" or "What clear water!"
Fourth, clothing. Never forget that your appearance reflects
not just on yourself but on the whole house. It was well enough
before you joined a sorority to lounge around campus in your
old middy blouse and gym bloomers, but now you must take
great pains to dress in a manner which excites admiring comments from all who observe you. A few years ago, for example,
there was a Chi Omega named Camille Ataturk at the University of Iowa who brought gobs of glory to all her sorors.

Comedy of Errors
Although on the surface it appears that the IFB is
doing a good job this year, if one scratches the epidermis,
a series of mishaps and miscalculations are revealed which
more than suggest that Decker and Co. has been sloughing
off in monstrous proportions.
We shall commence at the genesis of this administration. The fall formal, originally scheduled, was rescheduled due to a conflict with a Barnstormer date. This
miscalculation cost the IFB the use of the Dixie Ballroom,
the band it had originally contracted, and $417.38 of extraneous gymnasium costs, such as tables, chairs, linen,
service charges, and damage done to three decorative pine
trees.
Then the Bowman Cup, which was not presented on
time to AD, is less than half the size of the original cup,
retired this year by Phi Ep. The Bowman Certificates
have not yet been printed, because they are locked in the
IFB filing cabinet, and the keys are lost. The keys were
also lost to the office of the Vigilance Committee, hence no
fraternity has sat vigilance duty for months. But it makes
little difference anyway, as the phone has been taken out
of the office because Decker neither handed over phone bills
nor money to secretary-treasurer Maseritz.
If one recalls the Phi Sig-Phi Ep "dirty" rushing incident of the past semester, he will also recall the $100
fine levied against each fraternity, and the threat that the
involved freshmen would be called before the Board for
a thorough castigation and indocrination into the ways of
gentlemanly rushing. The freshmen were never called;
Phi Ep is yet to pay up; no $100, hence no paid phone
bills, hence no vigilance duty.
The committee established before Christmas vacation
to report upon a new rush system has not only failed to
report, but has also failed to meet in full force. At IFB
meetings, the recorder, never mimeos the minutes; consequently Maseritz shoulders the responsibility. When
questions of constitutionality arise, a constitution is never
available.
These are just the highlights.. Let's all have a good
laugh at the IFB's incompetence, and trust that it better
damn sight get on the ball.

The Facts of Life
Reaction to the announcement that the entering
Freshmen of September, 1958, will not be allowed to park
cars on the campus if they reside more than three-quarters
of a mile from the University, has been mixed. We have
heard everything from indignant "I don't like it one damn
bit," to "I don't have any kick. At other schools I wouldn't
even be able to have a car until my senior year."
The facts of life in regard to the University parking
dilemma are quite simple: there are too many cars for
available parking spaces. The answer to the problem isn't
so simple. The parking commission took the action because it felt that there were no more parking spaces available. Others have disputed this.
Wyman Park has been suggested, but typographical
studies of the area indicate that development would be
very expensive. It takes a 65 foot strip for two rows of
cars. Parking garages are extremely expensive. Underground facilities cost well over $2000 per car: Above-theground structures are priced at a minimum of $1300 per
car. The garages have not been discarded but they would
be a last step, for operation would be both difficult and
costly.
A third possibility is the further development of the
existing lot near the faculty club. We have not been given
a satisfactory answer as to why this area can't be expanded.
Since there are many more registered cars than available spaces, the only way the maximum number of drivers
can be accommodated is to have turnover. This new rule
is aimed at achieving greater turnover, to eliminate the
cars that are parked for days at a time.
But the dormitory residents need help also. We have
petitioned the parking commission requesting that they try
to have the two hour parking limit recinded on Charles
Street. At the present time the University parking facilities, with the exception of the tiny dormitory, lot, are
third choice for dormitory residents. Charles St. and
University Parkway are first on the list. Thus if the
parking commission can persuade the City to allow unlimited parking on the adjacent streets, the on-campus
storage problem will be greatly reduced.
